lesson.name: 2B EI Lesson Plan - Part 1: Lesson Introduction

page.title: Lesson Introduction and Self-regulation
page.contents:
A short standard set of opening lesson activities can help prepare students for new learning. Having a consistent routine for beginning each lesson allows learners to get set to be active participants in instruction (foster self-regulation).

Do you have a short standard way that you begin each class?
If you asked your students, “How do we usually begin class?” what would they say?  

Let’s explore how to design a lesson introduction that incorporates principles of explicit instruction. As we explore, compare this EI lesson introduction with your own practices.


Click on the Next button below to continue.

page.title: Lesson Introduction Components
page.contents:
Most AE instructors have some procedures they use to start off a lesson.  Let's compare these to the recommended components of an EI Lesson Introduction.

For EI Instruction, a lesson introduction should set up new learning by:

  1. Gaining students’ attention.
  2. Informing students of the lesson’s objective/s.
  3. Identifying reason/s to learn.
  4. Connecting to prior knowledge.
  5. Reviewing and checking for prerequisite skills.
  6. Pre-teaching vocabulary.

Let’s examine each of these 6 components more closely.

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: EI Lesson Introduction – Component #1
page.contents:
Gain Student Attention

This is a brief but important entry into the lesson which:

  • recognizes that learners are transitioning into the class from another activity, or within a class from one topic to another,
  • should take no more than a minute, and
  • consists of a simple teacher statement, question, or physical prompt(s).

Let's look at some examples and nonexamples of this lesson introduction component.

Examples

Nonexamples

"Please open your notebooks to the homework you did for this class. This will help us get started."

"Open your books to page 16."

"Why are decimals important in our daily lives?"

"It’s time to do some more writing."

"Welcome to class. Please look at me when you are ready to begin."

Teacher starts talking while students are talking to each other.

Teacher starts while students are still getting organized.

Teacher stands at door to greet students. When teacher goes to the front of the room, the lesson begins.

Teacher sits at front of the room and passes worksheet to students.

 

Review the nonexamples above – what makes each of them a nonexample of Gaining Students' Attention?

 

Click on Next below to continue.

page.title: Activity: Component #1 Nonexamples – Possible responses
page.contents:
While responses may vary, we’ve listed below one set of responses to why each of these is a nonexample of Gaining Students' Attention.

Nonexamples

What’s Wrong?

"Open your books to page 16."

General, non-motivating statement. What’s on page 16? Why open the book to page 16?

"It’s time to do some more writing."

General statement. What does it mean to do more writing?

Teacher starts talking while students are talking to each other.

The students who are talking aren’t paying attention. They are missing what the teacher is saying. This sends the message that what the teacher is saying isn’t important.

Teacher starts while students are still getting organized.

Students are still getting themselves settled and materials out. They are missing what is said.

Teacher sits at front of the room and passes worksheet to students.

There is no introduction or connection with learners.

 

Consider how you typically gain students’ attention before beginning instruction.
What might you want to change or improve?

 

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: EI Lesson Introduction – Component #2
page.contents:
Inform Students of the Lesson’s Objective/s

During this component of a lesson introduction, the instructor should:

  • Inform students of what they will be able to do as a result of the lesson.
  • Use learner-friendly language.
  • Help learners anticipate their role.
  • Give the message that there is a clear goal for the session.
  • Keep the objectives in mind and stay focused in planning and teaching.

Below are some examples and nonexamples of this lesson introduction component:

Examples

Nonexamples

"By the end of the session you will be able to explain the steps of writing a persuasive essay."

"Today you will answer the questions at the end of the chapter."

 

"By the end of this session you will be able to multiply with decimals."

"We are going to work on addition today."

 

"You will be able to picture what you read using the visualization strategy."

Written on the board: Given a 3 paragraph passage, students will be able to identify 1 main idea and 2 details for each paragraph with 80% accuracy.

 Adapted from Goeke, 2009, p.54


Review the nonexamples above.
What makes each of them a nonexample of Informing Students of the Lesson’s Objective/s?


Click Next below to continue.

page.title: Activity: Component #2 Nonexamples – Possible responses
page.contents:
While responses may vary, we’ve listed below one set of responses as to why each of these is a nonexample of ‘Informing Students of the Lesson’s Objective/s.

Nonexamples

What’s Wrong?

"Today you will answer the questions at the end of the chapter."

Tells students what they will do, not what they will learn.

"We are going to work on addition today."

This is a general statement - what does "work on addition" mean? What are students going to be able to do as a result of the lesson?

Written on the board: Given a 3 paragraph passage, students will be able to identify 1 main idea and 2 details for each paragraph with 80% accuracy.

Too technical, lack of user friendly language.



Do you start each lesson with a clear objective of what students will be able to do as a result of the session activities? How do you inform students of the learning outcomes they can expect for a lesson? What might you want to change or improve?
 

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: EI Lesson Introduction – Component #3
page.contents:
Identify Reasons to Learn

During this component of a lesson introduction, the instructor should conduct a short discussion with learners about the reasons for the lesson. This component addresses these typical learner questions:

  • Why learn this?
    The answer helps to motivate learners to pay attention and put forth effort.
  • Where and when can you use this?
    The answer helps to:
    • Connect the lesson with present and future situations.
    • Show how the lesson will help meet learning of school-related tasks and goals.
    • Show how the lesson will help meet functional/career-related tasks and goals.

Let's look at some examples and nonexamples:

Examples

Nonexamples

"What are some reasons you have for wanting to remember what you read?"

"You are going to practice the Visualization Strategy today."

"Who would like to be a better speller? How would that help you?"

"Based on the spelling quiz I gave you, I see we need more practice adding -ed and -ing to short vowel words."

"The paragraph writing we are doing this session will help you on the writing portions of the high school equivalency tests."

"We have a lot to do, so let’s get started."



Review the nonexamples above – what makes each of them a nonexample of Identifying Reasons to Learn?

 

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: Activity: Component #3 Non-Examples – Possible responses
page.contents:
Identify Reasons to Learn

While responses may vary, we’ve listed below one set of responses as to why each of these is a nonexample of Identifying Reasons to Learn.

Nonexamples

What’s Wrong?

"You are going to practice the Visualization Strategy today."

It informs students what they will be doing, not why they are doing it.

"Based on the spelling quiz I gave you, I see we need more practice adding -ed and -ing to short vowel words."

Why is it important to know the spelling rule beyond a quiz grade?

"We have a lot to do, so let’s get started."

No reason provided for what students will be doing.



How well do you think your students are able to tell you the reasons for what they are learning in your class?  How well are students using what you are teaching in their lives outside of school?
What would you enjoy about having brief rationale discussions with students? How might these discussions inform your teaching? [Note the discussion prompts in the previous examples.]

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: EI Lesson Introduction – Component #4
page.contents:
Connect to Prior Knowledge

There is a direct relationship between what a learner knows about a topic and how easy it is to learn more about the topic. New learning means that learners are able to make connections between what they already know and what they are currently learning.

We meet learners with two types of challenges:

  • Challenge 1  - The less you know, the fewer skills you have, the greater the learning challenge.
    These are our learners with major gaps in their prior learning in school. They must put forth extra effort to learn.

  • Challenge 2  - Many learners do not automatically search for prior knowledge connections.
    These are often learners who have experienced lack of success in school because of learning disabilities, family stressors, or disrupted schooling.  They have learned to take a passive stance to learning.  They need to learn that they can learn.


When activating prior knowledge it is important that you:

DO – connect with what students are familiar with in a way that is engaging and relates to meaningful contexts.
DON’T – use new vocabulary.

It is also important to help all students activate their prior knowledge, not just a few. Try a variety of techniques to engage students. Include all students in activities like:

  • a brief paper-pencil activity,
  • paired student discussions, and/or
  • whole group discussion.

Let’s next look at some examples and non-examples of connecting to a learner’s prior knowledge.

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: Activity: Component #4 Examples and Non-Examples
page.contents:
Connect to Prior Knowledge

Lesson: Introducing how to write a persuasive essay

Example

Nonexample

"If you wanted a boss to give you a raise, what would you do?"

"What does persuasive mean?"

Lesson: Types of animals in ecosystems include carnivores, herbivores and omnivores

Example

Nonexample

"Name 3 things you have eaten in the last week."

"Are humans carnivores, omnivores or herbivores?"

Lesson: Subtracting numbers with decimals

Example

Nonexample

"What do you buy that costs less than $1.00? More than $1.00?"
Students name items and provide an estimate of the cost. Teacher writes the responses on the board in a simple comparison chart.

"Work this problem: 10.75 - .99 = ?"

 

Review the nonexamples above.
What makes each of them a nonexample of Connecting to Prior Knowledge?

 

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: Activity: Component #4 Nonexamples – Possible responses
page.contents:
Connect to Prior Knowledge

While responses may vary, we’ve listed below one set of responses as to why each of these is a nonexample of Connecting to Prior Knowledge.

Lesson: Introducing how to write a persuasive essay

Example

Nonexample

"What does persuasive mean?"

Uses vocabulary that may not be familiar to the learners.

Lesson: Types of animals in ecosystems include carnivores, herbivores and omnivores

Example

Nonexample

"Are humans carnivores, omnivores or herbivores?"

Uses vocabulary that may not be familiar to the learners.

Lesson: Subtracting numbers with decimals

Example

Nonexample

"Work this problem: 10.75 - .99 = ?"

This is a decontextualized example. It does not connect to students’ real lives.


In your mind, identify an important skill or concept that you have recently taught.
What question or activity could help you connect to your students’ prior knowledge? 
Would this be a short written activity, paired student discussion, or whole group discussion?

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: EI Lesson Introduction – Component #5
page.contents:
Review and Check for Prerequisite Knowledge and Skills

Most skills and concepts build on previous learning. Prior to instruction, instructors should identify prerequisites to review, then develop a short activity to ensure that all students have the prerequisites.

Focus Objective

Prerequisite

Summarize a passage.

Identify the main idea of a passage.

Write a paragraph.

Knowledge of sentence structure and basic grammar.

Spell 1-syllable
short vowel words.

Identify short vowel sounds and match to appropriate letter.

Multiply decimals.

Multiply whole numbers.

Describe how a decimal is different from a whole number.

Describe characteristics
of capitalism.

Differentiate between goods and services, and public and private organizations.

Describe what happens
in photosynthesis.

Describe basic cell structure.


Below are some clarifying examples and non-examples of activities that check for prerequisite knowledge and skills:

Examples

Nonexamples

Give a short homework assignment of prerequisite knowledge and/or skills.
Then go over the homework at the beginning
of class.

Ask one or two students to come to the board to demonstrate.

Give a short "quiz" and review.

Review consists of asking students, “Do you remember...?”

Give a pretest prior to lesson. Teach/reteach any prerequisites needed prior to introducing the new information and/or skills
[the Explanation/Modeling step].

Reteach all students the prerequisites as part of the lesson introduction.


Below are some clarifying examples and non-examples of activities that check for prerequisite knowledge and skills:

Examples

Nonexamples

Give a short homework assignment of prerequisite knowledge and/or skills.
Then go over the homework at the beginning
of class.

Ask one or two students to come to the board to demonstrate.

 

Give a short "quiz" and review.

Review consists of asking students, “Do you remember...?”

Give a pretest prior to lesson. Teach/reteach any prerequisites needed prior to introducing the new information and/or skills
[the Explanation/Modeling step]. 

Reteach all students the prerequisites as part of the lesson introduction.

 

Review the nonexamples above.
What makes each of them a nonexample of a method for Reviewing and Checking for Prior Knowledge?

 

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: Activity: Component #5 Nonexamples – Possible responses
page.contents:
Reviewing and Checking for Prerequisite Knowledge and Skills

While responses may vary, we’ve listed below one set of responses as to why each of these is a non-example of Checking for Prerequisite Knowledge and Skills.

Nonexamples

What’s Wrong?

Ask one or two students to come to the board to demonstrate.

 

The teacher will only get information on the students who come to the board.

Review consists of asking students, “Do you remember…?”

Students may erroneously think they know or may be embarrassed to indicate they don’t remember.

Reteach all students the prerequisites as part of the lesson introduction.

Students may not need reteaching of all prerequisites, or not all students may need assistance. Also, effective reteaching takes time. If significant reteaching is needed, instructor needs to set aside the original lesson objective, and address the needed prerequisites.



Identify an important skill or concept that you teach.
What are the key prerequisite skills needed to master the skill or concept?
How can you review and check on these skills with your students?

Optional:  To learn more about activating prior knowledge, visit the resource below:    

NCAC Background Knowledge: Curriculum Enhancement Report

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: EI Lesson Introduction – Component #6
page.contents:
Preteach New Vocabulary

During this last component of an EI lesson introduction an instructor should briefly introduce key vocabulary words. These are words that are :

  • central to the content,
  • difficult to understand using context clues,
  • challenging to decode, and
  • probably not part of students’ oral vocabulary.

Goeke, 2009, pp. 66-67

Preteaching vocabulary:

  • Helps students anticipate challenging vocabulary they will be reading.
  • Can help activate students’ prior knowledge related to the new vocabulary.
  • Assists students in knowing what vocabulary is important to learn.


When preteaching vocabulary:

DO:

  • Select words that are most important for the new learning.
  • Present and discuss words in context.
  • Expand and enrich the meaning of the words by presenting them in varied contexts.
  • Keep vocabulary instruction engaging and fast-paced.

DON’T:

  • Create a long laundry list of words.
  • Simply require students to look up or memorize rote definitions.
  • Delay the lesson with long, tedious vocabulary instruction.


Let’s look at some examples and non-examples of how to effectively pre-teach vocabulary.

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: Activity: Component #6 Examples and Nonexamples
page.contents:
Preteach New Vocabulary

Examples

Nonexamples

Show a key vocabulary word in a sentence
from a passage students will be reading
and then discuss the meaning.

Give students a list of words to look up definitions.

 

Introduce the word “retrospect” by
discussing what the two word parts mean (“retro-” and “-spect”).

Give students a list of 25 challenging words in a passage.

After introducing a new word in context,
ask students to try out using the new word orally with a partner. Then debrief the students.

Give students a list of words and dictionary definitions to use when reading a passage.

 

Review the nonexamples above.
What makes each of them a nonexample of a method for Preteaching New Vocabulary?

 

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: Activity: Component #6 Nonexamples – Possible responses
page.contents:
While responses may vary, we’ve listed below one set of responses as to why each of these is a nonexample of a method for Preteaching of New Vocabulary.

Nonexamples       

What’s Wrong?

Give students a list of words to look up definitions.

 

Simply looking up definitions is not an effective or efficient method for learning new vocabulary.

Give students a list of 25 challenging words in a passage.

The teacher is presenting a laundry list of new words, probably not just the most important words.

Give students a list of words and dictionary definitions to use when reading a passage.

Students may not learn the meanings of the words, just rote definitions.

 

In your mind, identify a key vocabulary word in an upcoming lesson that you think will be unfamiliar to many of your students. How could you briefly preteach this word to your students in a way that will help them better comprehend the word during the lesson?

 

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: EI Lesson Introduction - Putting it all together
page.contents:
Now that we’ve looked at each of the Introduction components more closely, let’s once again consider how these elements fit together as a whole to promote learner self-regulation.

To review, the explicit instruction lesson format has an introduction consisting of the following 6 components:

  1. Gaining students’ attention
  2. Informing students of the lesson’s objective/s
  3. Identifying reason/s to learn
  4. Connecting to prior knowledge
  5. Reviewing and checking for prerequisite skills
  6. Preteaching vocabulary

Below, we’ve provided you with a tool to assist in designing and implementing an EI lesson introduction. Click on either link to download and save or print this planning tool for use in the activity below.

Explicit Instruction: Planning Your Lesson Introduction .doc file  - editable/printable

 
Now we ask you to view a video of a lesson introduction. 
As you watch, use the lesson introduction planning tool to:

  • identify the introduction components,
  • estimate the amount of time spent on each component, and
  • reflect on the introduction overall.

 Click on the Video button below to continue.

page.title: Activity – Video EI Lesson Introduction
page.contents:
Video - Alphabetics: Closed Syllable

Alphabetics: Closed Syllable

Video Transcript

If you are having trouble viewing the video, insert the link below in a new tab/window 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zTZ-oqSWMSc&t


 As you watch the video, take notes on what you observe.
Use the lesson introduction planning tool (linked below) to:

  • identify the introduction components,
  • estimate the amount of time spent on each component, and
  • reflect on the introduction overall.

Explicit Instruction: Planning Your Lesson Introduction .doc file - editable/printable
Explicit Instruction: Planning Your Lesson Introduction .pdf file - printable

 

This video is an excerpt from ones created by the California Adult Literacy Professional Development Project (CALPRO), a state Leadership Project of the California Department of Education (CDE), Adult Education Office. CALPRO produced them in collaboration with community adult schools of the Los Angeles Unified School District and the Outreach and Technical Assistance Network (OTAN). The videos were recorded and edited by Douglas Rennie of OTAN and they are copyright CALPRO 2011.  CDE and CALPRO have granted permission to include these excerpts in this free online professional learning course funded by OVAE and hosted on LINCS servers.

Click Next below to continue.

page.title: EI Lesson Introduction - Review and Reflection
page.contents:
In this section, we have examined an EI lesson format and its first component – the Lesson Introduction. We have also begun an exploration of how EI lesson components can support the important development of our students as self-regulated learners.

Now we ask you to reflect on what you have learned.
You will be asked to post your thoughts to a discussion forum.

 
How can you, as a teacher, use these six components (listed below) in a way that helps your students become self-regulated learners who:
  • set goals for their learning,
  • can describe their progress toward those goals, and
  • marshall their intellectual and emotional resources to solve problems and persist in working to master challenging content.
EI Lesson Introduction components:
  1. Gaining students’ attention
  2. Informing students of the session’s objective/s
  3. Identifying reason/s to learn
  4. Connecting to prior knowledge
  5. Reviewing and checking for prerequisite skills
  6. Preteaching vocabulary
Click Finish to end this lesson, return to the Main Course Menu, and access the Discussion Forum to post your reflection.
